title: Canavan cool on credits for carbon capture and storage projects
text:
''I certainly think looking at something like CCS should be considered but there is a whole lot of detail that (Energy Minister Angus Taylor) in particular will have to work through with the industry,'' he said.

''I would say at this stage of the CCS development stage, that ACCUs by itself would not be sufficient to attract or get that over the line.''

Mr Canavan pointed to two CCS for coal-fired power projects in North America – Canada's Boundary Dam and the Petra Nova project in Texas – as evidence that the cost of abatement was higher than the value of carbon credits, which has trended around $15 per unit this year.

''I have had some discussions with the industry about how they want to see it go forward, we are probably with CCS still at that phase where there is a bit of research and development to go,'' he said.

The comments come as the Morrison government promises to pump an extra $1 billion into the Clean Energy Finance Corporation, and follow reports of a heated clash between Mr Canavan and Prime Minister Scott Morrison last week over slow progress toward a feasibility study into a new coal-fired power station in Queensland.

The study was an election promise designed to soothe the National Party.

Asked what the Government should do to encourage a new coal-fired power station in Queensland, Mr Canavan said only the sovereign could reduce sovereign risk.

''There is an issue here to attract long-term finance for any kind of power station that has a payback period over five years. It is really tough in the current market with the uncertainty, particularly policy uncertainty, to make that investment, and the only person who can get rid of the sovereign issue is the sovereign,'' he said.

''So there is a role for governments to provide that security after that five-year period, like Rod Sims said, and that is what we are doing through schemes like [the] Underwriting New Generation [policy].

''We have a real need to increase the amount of baseload dispatchable power in the system, and so coal should be part of that mix.''

Mr Canavan has increasingly linked the debate over coal-fired power to the future of Australia's ailing aluminium industry, which has smelters at risk of closure in Queensland, Victoria and NSW.

''If you don't support coal-fired power you are kissing goodbye to a big chunk of our aluminium industry," he said.

Alcoa is in discussion with the Victorian government over whether hundreds of millions of dollars worth of subsidies can be extended when they expire in 2021.

The smelter is located in a safe Coalition seat held by Education Minister Dan Tehan, but Mr Canavan declined to say whether he believed the subsidies should be extended.

But Mr Canavan said subsidies for Portland were required because Victorian energy prices were made higher by state government policies that banned extraction of onshore gas and the exit of the Hazelwood coal-fired power station.
description: The resources minister stopped short of backing an industry push for carbon capture and storage to earn tradeable carbon credits.
